content:
Posted: April 2
												This game was an unexpected pleasure. The best way I found to enjoy it is to not ask too much of it, and simply let it be the casual gameplay experience it was meant to be. I bought the game because the gameplay videos showed the characters moving slowly and gracefully, and that chill pacing was with me throughout my playthrough. Here's how it breaks down:The Good - Here is an excellent title if you are looking for some laid-back fun. The game's pacing was just fast enough to keep things interesting, but slow enough to give you the time to take in the visuals and play with the game's 2D physics. The story was present enough to give the game some direction, but was unconcerned with details and complexity just like a picture book (and with the 2D gameplay and rich backgrounds it certainly felt like a picture book sometimes). The character control was pretty tight, not perfect, but close enough that I didn't find myself frustrated trying to jump onto small ledges. All of these elements came together to make for a pleasant few hours. The Bad - My only real complaint is that I wish there was more content (and I am downloading Trine 2 as I write this review so hopefully that will help). I finished the whole thing in about five hours. I had no technical issues. My controller worked perfectly and the game looked excellent without stutter or other problems. The Verdict - This is not a flashy game. It is not tense or super-fast-paced. You will not feel the rush of victory or the crush of defeat, because it never feels like much is at stake. But if you play this game with the understanding that it is a casual experience, and you are okay with something a little simpler, then I think you will find this game a comfortable match.

content:
Posted: April 17
												A friend of mine got me to buy the whole trilogy, so I'll review each of the three games on their respective pages.Visuals: The game is really pretty, I must say. The environments you travel through are beautiful almost the entire time. There are a few spots that look like generic corridors, but they are not very frequent.Music: The music is good, but the tracks are very short, meaning the music quickly becomes repetitive to the point of being annoying. You also can't turn it off completely, only lower its volume significantly, so once the music becomes annoying, you can't escape it.Story: The story is... alright... I guess... Not desperately interesting though. It feels more like an excuse plot than something that was given high priority.Combat: The combat is acceptable, has a nice flow to it, and there are multiple ways to approach it. However, the boss fights aren't particularly interesting. (There are also technically only two bosses. All subsequent ones are copy-pasted versions of them.)Platforming: This is what really brings the game down. The most important part of any platformer is to have good... well... platforming. This game does not. You frequently find yourself struggling against inconsistent collision boxes. The grappling hook helps, but it has restrictions on what angles you can shoot it in, and has a tendency to mess up the physics simulation occasionally.Other points of note: The final level increases the difficulty significantly. It's still manageable, but can easily get frustrating if you haven't yet gotten used to the awkward platforming.In conclusion: The game is acceptable, I guess... But not something I would recommend. The short music loops and frustrating platforming issues are the main things that bring it down. Most aspects of the game are kinda average, but the visuals are great. I can see how others would like the game, but I personally don't.(A quick note about the other games in the series: Trine 2 fixes most of the issues that this first game has, and is actually a pretty good game. Trine 3, on the other hand, has a couple of other issues that bring it down again.)

												This review is for the game ''Trine'',a side-scrolling action platform and puzzle video game,developed by the video game company ''Frozenbyte'' and published by Nobilis(wordwide).It was released in July 3,2009 for Microsoft Windows and since then the game has been released for the PlayStation Network,Mac OS X and for Linux as well.Trine uses the Proprietary engine.PlotTrine takes place in a magical but destroyed kingdom.After a brief period of peace,the king died without leaving any heir.So the kingdom descented to anarchy.During this political instability an undead army appears and attacks the kingdom destroying everything that's on its path.After some time three heroes,unkown to each other,reach the Astral Academy,a magical institution,where they touch a magical object,later said to be the Trine,and their souls bind together.After that incident they search for a way to free themselves of that peculiar effect.The trio must eventually undergoe  an adventure searching for three artifacts that once reunited they could be free.Apparently the Trine is the artifact of souls and without it the other two(the artifact of the body and the artifact of the mind) created the undead making them responsible for all the chaos that polutes the kingdom.After finding them they face a last ultimate challenge where they combine the Trine with the two lost artifacts,unbinding their souls forever.The game ends with the storyteller informing us that the kingdom has been cleansed from the undead and the three proclaiming it as its heroes.CharactersYou take control of Zoya,the thief,Amadeus,the wizard,and Pontius,the knight.Each of them has special abilities.Zoya is the stealthy one of the group and uses her bow and arrow,making her an exceptional marksman.Amadeus uses the power of magic,allowing him to conjur objects(planks,cubes,pyramids) helping the team to overcome obstacles and reach remote areas with great ease.Last but not least Pontius uses his sword,shield and sledgehammer with great force,making him the group's main damage dealer.The player is supposed to combine the group's power together in order to accomplish difficult stunts and unlock the group's true prowess.RecapIncredible game,breathtaking graphics,with exceptional yet simple plot.Enjoyed every bit of it and i definetely recommend it.Edit Friday 4 July 2014Trines has been updated with extremely good looking visual customizations and now is called Trine the Enchanted edition.You should try it out,everybody can be a Beta participant thanks to Frozenbyte developers.P.S Support the developers.Frozenbyte thank you for this game.

Posted: August 28, 2016
												Trine is a charming puzzle platformer with some light action elements. The artwork is gorgeous, the  soundtrack is great and the gameplay is fun. The Enchanted Edition is a port of the original game to the Trine 2 engine and the improved graphics still hold up surprisingly well.The game is rather reminiscent of Lost Vikings and puts you in control of three different characters with different abilities. Unlike in Lost Vikings, most of the puzzles in Trine are physics based. Unfortunately they all tend to be on the easy side. Especially late in the game you are given so many tools that pretty much any puzzle becomes trivial.The combat is rather casual too, and overall I found the game quite easy even on hard difficulty. The last two levels are significantly more challenging, though. At least you can switch difficulty on the fly, so this shouldn't be a major issue.Despite these minor faults Trine is a highly enjoyable game that's recommended to anyone who likes platformers.The good:- Beautiful art that still holds up quite well- Fun Lost Vikings inspired gameplay- Interesting fairytale story- Great soundtrackThe bad:- Big difficulty bump for the last two missions. The game is really easy even on hard before those two

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												What a beautiful game. If there are any people out there who have read my other reviews with any regularity, you know that I am not a fan of puzzle platformers. With early access and indie development being so accessible, the market is flooded with crappy 2D platformers and just the thought of them puts a sour taste in many peoples mouths.Trine enters the “2 1/2”D realm because the environment and models are all done in gorgeous 3D and it is only movement which is restricted to a flat plane. The gameplay actually surprised me because it focuses a good amount on combat, bringing in a sort of metroidvania feel without the exhaustive and often tedious backtracking. You can freely swap between one of three characters: a knight, thief and wizard. The knight is a go-to for combat while the thief covers mobility and the wizard... well he makes boxes. I found myself almost exclusively using the thief while only briefly swapping to the wizard to spawn in a box or plank. Meanwhile the knight sat around in limbo collecting dust between boss fights. It really felt like the characters were extremely balanced on paper but in practice the thief really is the main character, only needing the wizard to make some new platforms and the knight to smack around anything she can’t keep at bay with her bow.The good parts of Trine are really good, and while I feel that the characters aren’t balanced quite right this doesn’t take away from the writing, animation and overall quality this game brings to the table.

												Trine is a game I can't recommend enough.  It's a physics platformer with a rather unique mechanic of 3 playable characters.  They are tied together by magic so you can switch between them at any time and use their abilities to make your way through the levels.  Puzzles are quite varied requiring a number of different strategies, especially if you want to collect all the experience orbs which can be quite difficult to reach.  All of the characters are well-balanced and necessary to proceed through the game.  The game is also very well-written and acted which is a welcome change from most platformers.Where Trine really shines though is the graphics.  The art in this game is absolutely stunning and it's amazing how well it runs even on older hardware.  It also makes use of nVidia PhysX for high quality physics simulation (nVidia hardware not required.)  The world and levels are very well designed and quite engrossing as well.The only thing this game is missing is coop, but that was added for the sequel which is just as awesome.  Play them both!  You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Just finished Trine in the free-weekend.I wanted to play this game for a while, and I took advantage of this opportunity to finally try it out. I am not disappointed, but I'm not fully pleased either.TL;DR review = Beautiful looking game, impressive degree of immersion for the genre through graphics, sounds and writing. Gameplay mechanics are not terrible, but they are the weakest link in this game. Not a deal breaker though, game is worth a try.TL review:Gameplay: I know quick-time events are not a necessity for side-scrolling platformers, but when you have a rich 3d environment and heavy physics, they become important. Case in point, the grapling hook from the Thief seems often buggy (often goes through stuff you can jump on, breaks with no clear reason, etc), staying on platform edges or jumping on them can be more tricky than it should, and creating platforms with the wizard can prove difficult if there's the slightest denivalation in the terrain (boxes start to roll, etc). Combat is pretty repetitive and non-interesting, you don't have a lot of moves/attacks, and enemies have an attack animation that doesn't really land with the effect.One more thing; this might be an intended mechanic, or because of time and/or development constraints was not implentend: moving/dropping non-attached stuff with your wizard. It kind of feels like moving an object in editing software; physics are mostly there for the move part, but the drop part is just like dropping from a fixed point with no velocity, no matter what.GraphicsThis is where the game shines. It looks gorgeus. There's a heavy accent on colours and detail, a beautiful 3d environment with a fixed side-scrolling 2d camera. The style gives every setting the feeling of magic, especially the outdoor forest parts. It's also not extremely demanding, at least in the original version; I was able to run it with an acceptable framerate on an outdated low-end laptop, and it looked great. Enchanted Edition wasn't all that spec friendly :D. DesignStory - Not bad. It's sort of like a narrative that you knew as a child, a tale of heroes bound together, who overcome obstacles to reach individual goals, but find that their bond changes their perception, and seemingly work together for the greater good.Sounds - The music in this game is great. It fits perfectly with the story/writing, and with the adequate graphics behind it, it's conveying a sense of immersion. The sound effects and voice acting aren't bad either, but it's the music that truly shines.Levels - The levels are not too difficult, ergo this game is not too difficult. You may find it troublesome to get some achievements, but all in all it's pretty balanced, at last until the last level, which seems to jump the volume of difficulty to 150% (from 100% obviously...idk, I had no better analogy...). Again, it's not THAT difficult, it's just that the game progresses really smoothly in difficulty, not really increasing or decreasing by much, and at the last one, BOOM, it's like you switched from normal to hard (this game doesn't have a difficulty option, btw).ConclusionWell...what can I say, I enjoyed it, even though gameplay mechanics kind of frustrated me. I'll put some of that on my rig though, and considering I'm recommending this game, what I found problematic isn't that much of a problem.

Posted: May 3, 2014
												Even on its own, Trine is a visual puzzle-platform delight, containing 15 levels (plus 1 bonus level) for you to journey through. If you remember the old console game "The Lost Vikings", then know that this is a slightly faster-paced version with more emphasis on combat, as well as beautiful backdrops to the various levels.The game has you play as 3 characters (wizard, thief, and knight) fused into one existence; during play, you can freely call in one of the three to handle fights or puzzles, while the other two hover in a mental limbo. Depending on your tastes, you may relish the idea that the game's puzzles are generally flexible, and let a player choose one of many ways to solve a puzzle. You can conjure planks as a wizard to reach a ledge, or simply grapple to the top as a thief. Even combat is up to you, fight head-on as a knight, at range as a thief, or use a wizard to conjure blocks that crush.Though the game has its downsides. The enemies are bland, with only a majority of skeletons and two other generic creatures. After a while, combat with them becomes a chore to check-off inbetween puzzles. The story is nice, but has little involvement with the gameplay, as the plot comes in verbal chunks during 3 sections: the loading screen; the level beginning; and the level end. The game itself is quite linear and straight-forward, with only small branches that lead to secret collectibles, that in turn upgrade the three heroes' abilities.However, note that this game has a Local Co-op option that I did not try.Overall, this game is more like an appetizer instead of a main course; it lets you get used to how the game mechanics work and tells you the backstory of Trine 2, and you could finish this in less than a day. If you strip away the distractions of plot and combat, Trine is purely a quick (though not without some thought) mildly-challenging puzzle game. Still, I heartily recommend this game as it is a brisk body-swapping romp through a scenic fantasy world. If you want this game, get it purely for its pretty puzzles.NOTE: Trine is packaged with Trine 2 in the packages "Trine Complete" and "Frozenbyte Collection" which may make your purchase more worthwhile, particularly during a Steam Sale.

Posted: February 14, 2015
												I was very happy from start to finish playing Trine. Trine is a relatively short platformer that uses 3 distinct characters with unique skills to help you progress and collect all the experience bottles throughout each level. You can change characters on the fly just by pressing 1, 2 or 3. The visuals are stunning and I was constantly just looking at the scenery. The sound is equally good, with fantastic music that suited each level. It's worth noting the sound effects were all great and of very high quality. There are several different enemies and "bosses" throughout the game. However, the enemies lack variety and will constantly repeat over and over. I put bosses in quotes because they are actually quite easy. Maybe mini-bosses is a better term. Trine is a very forgiving game (played on the default difficulty). It's easy to pick up and play a level. It never gets very difficult and has a very generous checkpoint/revival system. The story is as good as it can be for a game like this. There's not much too it, but it’s conveyed well to the player through a fantastic narrator. The controls are ok. Sometimes I got frustrated with my character motion and jumping onto ledges. But it is a minor gripe. To fix my framerate stutter +I ran an uncapped fps and left it to vsync to run at 60fps. This caused stuttering every couple of seconds. I fixed this by telling Trine in the options to run at a capped 60fps. Completely smooth after thatFix input lag+Another easy fix. My mouse input lag was pretty bad. Trine has an option to reduce lag. You'll want to put a check mark in that boxPros+Beautifully styled graphics.+Sound design is solid.+Overall platforming is fun.+Game rewards you (with experience) for exploring corners and trying to find the secret chests.+Smooth 60fps+Stable. Never crashed on my Windows 8.1 machine+Great narrator voice acting.+Fun puzzles and having to think how to progress furtherCons+Not much to the story.+At times I fought with the controls+Default difficulty could be a little more challenging+Only a few useful power-ups. A lot of them don't affect the characters much. (This may change when played on a harder difficulty)+Very few unique enemies.8/10 Very goodI would absolutely recommend Trine. The regular price of $14.99 seems a little much. I would not pass this up if it goes on sale. I got the Trine collections for $2.49 during the 2014 Summer Sale.

Posted: April 25, 2016
												This review is for the original, non-enchanted edition as I had already started with the original and never found the time to finish it of until now. I may go through the game again on enchanted to see what differences there are besides better graphics....and while I'm at it, I might as well go for 100% completion so that means getting the remaining achievements I haven't already got from running with the original....Oooohhh, I don't know why I started this on Hard difficulty(but didn't change it because I don't like changing difficulty half way through a game so I stuck with it)....hahaha - guess I thought I could take the heat! Apparently not so died so many times! hahaha... Actually I probably won't bother with 100% achievement completion(But I will try to get as close to that though) as I just took a glance and one of them was completing it on the hardest difficulty, which would be the next level up from Hard as this is the 2nd hardest(unless there's harder - there's apparently hardcore mode mentioned in the descriiption of that achievement....). Anyways, it's a puzzle, platformer, action and adventure game. That's what the genres should be, but it was tagged as only action adventure... So you start the game when the three characters collide with each other and combined into one being(I can't remember the exact details on how this happened as I started the game a couple or so years ago but never finished it), they are the Thief, Knight and Wizard. Thief's a  woman and the other two are guys. So are set out to find the other two powers(I forgot what the other two were called - lol and just finished a several minutes ago! haha), you have Trine. After that, the three beings as one will seperate into themselves again. So gameplay is you can do local coop, or coop on seperate PCs and can play each of three characters, or if you don't have people to play with you can solo it, like I did. When soloing, you can switch between the three to use their unique abilities and strengths to overcome obstacles in your way. I would imagine it would be more fun and quicker/easier if you had someone or two to play with and they control the other two characters... If you know platform type games like oldschool mario, then I don't need to explain any further as it's similar to that, with added puzzles. If not, then you basically jump and down - killing and or avoiding enemies, solving puzzles, and the screen sidescrolls for you automatically as you progress into the level. Graphics, yeah I thought the original Trine graphics was nice and pretty with everything maxed. Had average fps  of about 67-ish. The physic in this game, which uses nVidia's PhysX system, was awesome! Another one of those rare PhysX games. Audio, well I can say that it actually made full use of my 7.2 surround sound setup - surprised as it's a sidescroller platformer type game which I would have though stereo would be enough, but nope! The atmosphere and music was great! The voice overs were cool too. Sound effects were nice. Posted: November 24, 2011
												This game is beautiful. It's fun. It manages not to frustrate the hell out of you. Plus the lovely Thief has the voice of Isabela from Dragon Age 2. You can shoot skeletons, smash 'em, chop 'em or just drop something heavy onto them. The puzzles are not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like they are in some games and... wheee grappling hoooooooo...Quite frankly, the visuals are stunning. I'm normally not one to focus on graphics but Trine is really excellent. Which is good, because it's not one of the soulless, mass-produced turds that get released so much lately. That could tempt you to think it's just the visuals. but no, as I said - while it depends on the player, I found the balance between combat, puzzles and platforming quite appealing. There are also things to pick up for all the completionists, so you might find yourself replaying Trine if you're that kind of a person. I guess my main gripe with the game could be that it doesn't really have big flaws. It's not frustrating, you might actually consider that one. I don't. The game isn't really particularly hard, except possibly finding all the hidden thingamajigs. While there's not much of variety in opponents, they're not exactly the main focus either and the levels actually show variety. Which is pretty good, as copy-pasting is a pretty nasty sin.Trine hits quite a few nice spots and it calls back to the nostalgia days of Super Mario, just without taking the wrong cues - instead of picking up the ugly graphics and frustration, it takes the spirit of platforming and adds a spin on it. And while it uses physics for its puzzles, it avoids the pitfalls of that fairly well, delivering quite consistent results to what you do. It also gives you freedom to approach a few places in different ways, which is good - but as my memory serves, that resulted in me mostly using the Thief and the Wizard, with the Knight just doing bugger all except freak accidents when he was actually needed.The game is pretty good, if a little short. I'm a bit on the fence whether it's a good thing or not, but then again it does avoid the pitfall of stretching everything too far and lets you have some carefree fun in between things. It's not even particularly rough around the edges, so it's definitely worth checking out.

Posted: February 26, 2016
												I seriously LOVE this game. You will, too. Go play it. It's a physics-based puzzle-platformer with combat as well, with collectibles. It seriously has everything. You can alternate at will with three different characters, a knight (good at fighting, has a shileld, can smash things), a thief (ranged weapon, can grapple to things), and a wizard (who can summon boxes, planks and floating platforms). Each level is filled with traps, platforms, undead skeletons summoned around you to attack, and you're constantly switching between characters. Want to kill that far-off archer? Use your thief to shoot it. Surrounded by melee baddies? Use your knight. Need to cross a dangerous pit? Use your wizard to summon things to make a path. There are tons of different ways to play, too. Trying to reach a high up ledge with a collecible on it? You can 1) shoot down the wood planks holding it up (if possible), 2) platform jump some tricky moves, 3) build a tower of blocks or a plank bridge and just walk right over to it, 4) summon something and use it to knock the collectible from the ledge to the ground. There are certain tasks that can only be done with a certain character, or need to be done with a certain character if you haven't upgraded another one sufficiently, but usually there are tons of different ways to brute force a problem.Pros:+Great art. Fantasy setting with lots of giant mushrooms and sparkling fairy plants in woodland settings, creepy dungeons with lava, broken down castles with poisonous goop.+Adjustable difficulty. The default is medium (which is what I played at) and there are sometimes a bunch of baddies swarming on you all at once, but they're usually three weak hits to kill the weak ones, then you start getting better equipped baddies with shield or armor that take more hits. You can play on easy and (I assume) have less baddies or easier to kill ones, or harder if you like a challenge. I'm going to definitely replay on a harder difficulty at some point because this game is truly awesome.+Pretty good music, never setting too serious a tone to fit the style of the game. Baroque fantasy.+MANY ways to solve puzzles, and they're never TOO challenging. Very fun.+Variety of puzzles. Running away from lava, fighting spiders in the dark, low-stress puzzles, complicated platform jumping, etc.+Decent voice acting. Not amazing (except for maybe the thief), but not intrusive or annoying.+XP and leveling. You collect XP through fighting, but also as collectibles. So the more adventurous you are trying to find the hidden ones, the more you level. There's a limited but interesting set of skills to upgrade, making your fighter tougher and making him charge and fling objects at people, and allowing your wizard to summon more objects, making puzzle and platforming easier, and making your thief shoot more arrows, or light things on fire, etc.+Fair checkpoints. Also, if one of your characters dies, you can switch to another. Anytime you want to revive a dead one, just go back to a checkpoint and they return with limited health. This helps A LOT if you really need the wizard for a puzzle but he just got murdered.Cons:-Uh...I'm getting really nitpicky here, because it's just a superbly fun, well-crafted game, but the final boss level has very few checkpoints, but it's the boss so I totally understand.10/10. Will play again. And the sequel.

Anyways, it's a puzzle, platformer, action and adventure game. That's what the genres should be, but it was tagged as only action adventure... So you start the game when the three characters collide with each other and combined into one being(I can't remember the exact details on how this happened as I started the game a couple or so years ago but never finished it), they are the Thief, Knight and Wizard. Thief's a  woman and the other two are guys. So are set out to find the other two powers(I forgot what the other two were called - lol and just finished a several minutes ago! haha), you have Trine. After that, the three beings as one will seperate into themselves again. So gameplay is you can do local coop, or coop on seperate PCs and can play each of three characters, or if you don't have people to play with you can solo it, like I did. When soloing, you can switch between the three to use their unique abilities and strengths to overcome obstacles in your way. I would imagine it would be more fun and quicker/easier if you had someone or two to play with and they control the other two characters... If you know platform type games like oldschool mario, then I don't need to explain any further as it's similar to that, with added puzzles. If not, then you basically jump and down - killing and or avoiding enemies, solving puzzles, and the screen sidescrolls for you automatically as you progress into the level. Graphics, yeah I thought the original Trine graphics was nice and pretty with everything maxed. Had average fps  of about 67-ish. The physic in this game, which uses nVidia's PhysX system, was awesome! Another one of those rare PhysX games. Audio, well I can say that it actually made full use of my 7.2 surround sound setup - surprised as it's a sidescroller platformer type game which I would have though stereo would be enough, but nope! The atmosphere and music was great! The voice overs were cool too. Sound effects were nice. I believe it must be thanks to the EAX checkbox I ticked....Um not sure what else to say...I liked it enough to give it a thumbs up, though some of the parts are fustrating especially the timing bits and to add skeletons attacking you at the sametime that you have to avoid or and kill off....hah....the last level.....oh god......almost raged but got through it in the end! hahahaha Oh and once you've finished the game, you unlock a harder difficulty, Very Hard - which I'm not even gonna bother with(Hard was fustrating enough for me thanks!)...hahahaha...also there's a new level that unlocks which appears to be similar to the last level of the game.........................................................So yeah....you like solving puzzles? Like a bit of adventure, action too? Do you like them platformer type sidescrolling games as well? Posted: February 26, 2016
												I seriously LOVE this game. You will, too. Go play it. It's a physics-based puzzle-platformer with combat as well, with collectibles. It seriously has everything. You can alternate at will with three different characters, a knight (good at fighting, has a shileld, can smash things), a thief (ranged weapon, can grapple to things), and a wizard (who can summon boxes, planks and floating platforms). Each level is filled with traps, platforms, undead skeletons summoned around you to attack, and you're constantly switching between characters. Want to kill that far-off archer? Use your thief to shoot it. Surrounded by melee baddies? Use your knight. Need to cross a dangerous pit? Use your wizard to summon things to make a path. There are tons of different ways to play, too. Trying to reach a high up ledge with a collecible on it? You can 1) shoot down the wood planks holding it up (if possible), 2) platform jump some tricky moves, 3) build a tower of blocks or a plank bridge and just walk right over to it, 4) summon something and use it to knock the collectible from the ledge to the ground. There are certain tasks that can only be done with a certain character, or need to be done with a certain character if you haven't upgraded another one sufficiently, but usually there are tons of different ways to brute force a problem.Pros:+Great art. Fantasy setting with lots of giant mushrooms and sparkling fairy plants in woodland settings, creepy dungeons with lava, broken down castles with poisonous goop.+Adjustable difficulty. The default is medium (which is what I played at) and there are sometimes a bunch of baddies swarming on you all at once, but they're usually three weak hits to kill the weak ones, then you start getting better equipped baddies with shield or armor that take more hits. You can play on easy and (I assume) have less baddies or easier to kill ones, or harder if you like a challenge. I'm going to definitely replay on a harder difficulty at some point because this game is truly awesome.+Pretty good music, never setting too serious a tone to fit the style of the game. Baroque fantasy.+MANY ways to solve puzzles, and they're never TOO challenging. Very fun.+Variety of puzzles. Running away from lava, fighting spiders in the dark, low-stress puzzles, complicated platform jumping, etc.+Decent voice acting. Not amazing (except for maybe the thief), but not intrusive or annoying.+XP and leveling. You collect XP through fighting, but also as collectibles. So the more adventurous you are trying to find the hidden ones, the more you level. There's a limited but interesting set of skills to upgrade, making your fighter tougher and making him charge and fling objects at people, and allowing your wizard to summon more objects, making puzzle and platforming easier, and making your thief shoot more arrows, or light things on fire, etc.+Fair checkpoints. Also, if one of your characters dies, you can switch to another. Anytime you want to revive a dead one, just go back to a checkpoint and they return with limited health. This helps A LOT if you really need the wizard for a puzzle but he just got murdered.Cons:-Uh...I'm getting really nitpicky here, because it's just a superbly fun, well-crafted game, but the final boss level has very few checkpoints, but it's the boss so I totally understand.10/10. Will play again. And the sequel.

Oh, and in case none of your friends have the game but you still want to collaborate with other people while playing, remember that Trine also has an online mode. The thief is great because she can reach high up places and the knight is just kickass for when you have a lot of enemies around you. I favoured the thief the most due to her ability to grapple onto any wooden surface and climb the grapple rope. Following her closely I favoured the wizard as he can get your other characters around very fast. I love the idea of having 3 characters merged into one interchangable character, makes the gameplay really smooth.This game took me 5 and a half hours to complete, and that was on medium. The last mission is pretty insane and very fast paced. It has a great immersive world and it can keep you occupied for ages. Great time killer as the missions aren't massively long but there are nifty little hide-aways that have experience vials and chests, that if you play with the intention to fully play a mission, can take you quite a while. For a 2.5D game it is very enjoyable, I highly recommend it.8/10

Posted: August 22, 2013
												One of the better indie titles out there, unforuntunately limited by somewhat questionable game design.While the levels and puzzles are gloriously thought out and realised, it's all built around how the developers intended the game to be played: with 3 people controlling each of the characters.This is important, because along with this assumption, the developers neglected to include online play, and made it local only. This meant the vast majority of people played it as a singleplayer game.And what happens in singleplayer? You ninja through the levels as the theif, bypassing many of the more challenging and enjoyable puzzles the game has to offer.Glorious graphics and co-operative design, but unless you have two others that are going to be playing with you, in the same room, with controllers (I mean really?), then you aren't really playing it as it should be played.Thankfully this was remedied in the second game.

												Trine was absolutely spectacular. I usually do not enjoy many platformer games, but in this case, I was pleasantly surprised. The visual aspect of the game is just gorgeous. The lighting really does make it feel 'enchanted' (enchanted edition). However, this alone is not what makes this game spectacular. It is the fact that there are so many creative ways in which you can complete puzzles and get about and around in the game that made me stick around. You play as 3 people whose souls are stuck in the Trine. If you play alone, then you have to switch out between the Wizard, the Thief, and the Warrior. Each character has different special abilities, giving you the opporunity to solve the same puzzles in so many different ways. As a gamer, it really makes you feel creative when you solve a difficult puzzle/climb a difficult part of a level in your own unique way. It is all up to you in how you will get around in the game, whether it be using the Thief's grappling hook or the wizard's floating platform (etc). This game is amazing because there are no limits and no standards to how you solve a puzzle/level. It is all up to your imagination :). This is definitely worth playing!

Posted: March 7, 2016
												Quick Summary: Side scrolling platformer with great graphics and some tricky (but not too tricky) puzzle solving and light combat. Great game for casual co-op as well.You play a trio of heroes trapped in a single body by a mysterious magical artifact called the Trine. While your souls are bound, you can be any one of the three characters at any time: Wizard, Thief, or Knight. Your quest is to find out why you’re bound together and how to undo the “curse.” The game is played with keyboard and mouse though other players can drop in using a game controller on the same computer. You progress mostly from left to right in a two dimensional plane with a lot of jumping and scrambling from one level to another. With a press of a button you can instantly switch between the three characters, each with their unique skills useful for fighting (knight) grappling (thief) or conjuring objects to use (wizard). Each of the characters has their own life bar so if they die you need to either make do with the other 2 characters or backtrack until you get to a checkpoint (a glowing sphere). You can backtrack as much as you want in this game, which is useful since there are a lot of collectibles to be found. The collectibles mainly come in the form of experience potions, and when you level up you can upgrade skills unique to each character class (for example increasing the number of objects the wizard can have conjured at any one time).Pros:+Amazing graphics for a little indie game. The environments look 3D despite being a simple side scroller.+Free upgrade to the Enchanted Edition. The upgraded version uses the Trine 2 engine and got a large number of new Steam achievements.+Nice story with good narration. The narrator appears as an announcer in Dota 2 so you may recognize his voice.Cons: Not much really, the game is awesome.This is a great, cheap game that anyone can get into. If you didn’t get it for free sometime in the past you can probably see it in Humble Bundles occasionally. Play with friends and family!

Posted: April 14
												PROS+ Graphics/VisualsThe graphics in Trine are colorful and enveloped in a vibrant bloom, creating a magical and dream-like ambiance. The beauty is even more apparent when playing at 4K resolution or downsampled from such. + MusicThe music is pleasant and fits nicely with the visual style; also pizzicato strings rule. CONS- Faulty ControlsIronically, controls are wonky considering platforming is a core mechanic of the game. One of my problems was, for example, turning around on a dime and then jumping onto a platform; this often resulted in not grasping onto a ledge and falling, making fast platforming difficult. It was often more practical to give yourself extra space, turn around, wait for a second, and then attempt a jump. If this issue sounds strange, trust me, you would know what I am talking about if you played for yourself. Something else I noticed was that tapping the jump key as oppose to a longer press would cover a shorter distance. As a consequence, if you had to jump multiple platforms in quick succession, you would often fail and have to repeat, making for irksome moments. Finally, the character would at many times fail to grasp onto to a ledge despite clearly being able to do so; once again, leading to frustration. - Basic CombatThere is nothing special about the combat in Trine; it is quite shallow with no outstanding features. The one character, Amadeus, is next to useless for combat because he has no proper attack. You have to summon a cube, levitate it above an enemy, and let it fall crushing him. Attacking like this is fun at first but gets old, and is far too slow especially when dealing with several foes. With Amadeus being incompetent, only the other two characters are practical for fighting.- Underwhelming and Skippable PuzzlesPuzzles were not impressive since none really stood out to me. Making matters worse, are the character abilities which make many portions of the game skippable. A prime example would be conjuring Amadeus' triangle block and then using Zoya's grapple to transverse over an area in a way not intended. Even Amadeus alone is a problem since you can summon several blocks and planks to advance effortlessly. You could avoid upgrading Amadeus fully, but self-imposed limitations are never fun.- Repetitive GameplayTrine's gameplay is repetitious due to the reuse of content throughout the game. Not much changes in regards to combat, platforming, and puzzles, thus being a bit of a bore to play.- Difficulty CurveMost of the playthrough is far too easy, even on hard; however, once reaching the final level, the difficulty suddenly spikes. In this last level, you have to rush intensifying previously mentioned problems leading one to curse out loud. The difficulty curve which stagnates for the most part and then suddenly shoots up hurts this title big time.CONCLUSIONThe visuals and music of Trine are charming but do little for the overall experience. The combination of core mechanics is admittedly interesting but unfortunately dissonant to the extent of fundamentally breaking gameplay. Then there are other issues adding further insult to injury; I can not recommend this game. Ultimately, I give Trine a PAR of 1.IMPORTANT: I use PARS instead of a standard 1-10 scale. For more information, please visit http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067268268/images and click on the picture named "Positive Asymmetrical Rating Scale."

Posted: June 10, 2016
												   Ok let me start by saying any criticism aside, that I straight up loved this game and look forward to playing the next 2. However there are some pros and cons to the beautiful Trine: Enchanted Edition. As just mentioned this games design and beauty is what immediately drew me in and is what compelled me to buy the trilogy on steam and give it a run.   Trine is a platformer that uses three main characters who you are able to swap between to complete different tasks in the level. The Mage who can summon different items that become very useful, the Thief who is the archer of the group, & the Warrior who can take on foes face to face.   The flaws in Trine are minimal but almost all have to do with AI. The enemies wander into their own demise quite often, which doesn’t take you out of the game experience quite as much as when the bosses stomp right off the cliff. This usually happens when he is chasing you and your character falls off the cliff as well, but when you swap characters or respawn the boss is still gone which leads to some overly simplistic battles.   The story in Trine is kind of throw away, and serves more as a loading screen filler than anything. For this kind of game though that is actually a pretty good fit & did not leave me wanting more narrative. There is a narrator who explains the heroes plight and what they are about to delve into before each level.   So as you can imagine, the enemies and bosses killing themselves of can make for some pretty easy levels. I flew through the regular levels with relatively no problem, but when you come to the last level prepare to strap yourself in for a doozy. No matter how far you get, unless you reach the one check point at the very top, you will be sent straight back to the beginning over and over. This type of push back on the last level always endears a game to me I think the completion of a game should be a challenge and in that area Trine delivers.    My experience with the first of the Trine trilogy most definitely has me looking forward to the other two, & with the company partnering with GameStop for publishing on a new project, now is a good time to dig into the games if you haven’t already.For more video game news & reviews be sure to follow the blogHttp://www.SublimeGameReviews.wordpress.com & follow on instagram & twitter @SublimeReviews

												I personally like new twists on old classics, so I look for influences of good oldies in newer games. So when I was first introduced to “Trine”, I was all like: here are new “The Lost Vikings” (by Blizzard, 1992): three characters, each one with his strength and weaknesses complementing each other and solving little puzzles to complete levels.“Trine” is not, of course a copy of “Vikings”: it is more of an action, the puzzles are a bit easier, characters transform to each other, not being present on screen simultaneously (much like Silmarils’ “Metal Mutant” of 1991). Of course game looks much and much better, the world is designed beautifully,Game’s characters get experience from killing monsters and finding secrets, which can also contain unique items. Level-ups make them stronger in combat and platforming.So if you are into mildly difficult puzzle-platformers with a bit of RPG elements, you should check this one out.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
Short version: 91%Trine is an enchanting old-school platformer with three unique main characters and excellent level design. It suffers from some difficulty issues, especially in the end, yet those can be easily forgiven when you get yourself lost in the immersive visuals.Long version:Indie platformers on PC are far from being rare, but seldom do we see a gem like Trine. The largest selling point of the game is the breathtaking visual style and carefully constructed, detail-rich levels. The backgrounds are just teeming with and movement, making you feel you are playing in a living 3D environment, even though the gameplay itself is limited to 2D.The game itself is a very traditional platformer, where the levels require agility and a bit of resilience to get through. You also get three characters with distinctive abilities, but they all seem to lack personality. Although the original design suggests that all three are needed to clear the levels, in reality most stages are beatable by using mostly, or only the Thief. Despite this shortcoming, the level design is fun, and gathering all the (optional) experience can be a challenging, but not impossible task.The only part where the game falls short– like most platformers– is the story, which really boils down to: “Evil wizard is evil, go kill.” Still, the narration is pleasant and the banter among the three reluctant heroes is entertaining enough to keep you interested in the simple plot line.You can also switch to the Enchanted edition in the Betas tab, where the engine is replaced by the sequel’s, but even though I can run Trine 2 with no problems, the Enchanted edition suffered massive frame drops for me, so I can’t judge the upgrade.

												Trine is basically The Lost Vikings as a physics-based puzzle platformer, offering three characters with very different skillsets and many ways you can use them to approach the game's puzzles and challenges. It's not terribly hard unless you play it on the hardest difficulties, mostly due to offering infinite lives and copious checkpoints, but it always feels like a fun adventure and doesn't lack for challenge, even if you'll be able to respawn until you complete it eventually.Plus it's got an amusing sense of humor and a solid artstyle, and with the Enchanted Edition upgrade, online multiplayer for when you want to help (or screw over) your friends through the levels. It's hard to not recommend Trine to anyone who's interested in puzzle platformers at all.

Posted: April 23, 2014
												Truly one of the most impressive games I've ever played. The art alone is worth buying this, but the game is actually really fun and well done also. As for the art, it's not just the drawings/models/textures, but the animation is pure genius as well. Every moving thing in the game is done with absolute perfection, and even though it's sort of a "2d platformer" as for genre, everything is done in 3D with great precision. Just the way the warrior blocks with his shield clearly has sooo much time and thought put into perfecting the action. And everything else is done with just as much care. I don't have as much detail to say about them, but the music and sound effects are just as great as the visual effects, and clearly just as well-perfected. The physics are absolutely perfect, again done with absolute precision and perfection, with almost real life precision and realism. I'm on I think the 5th level, and there isn't a *ton* of combat, but there's just enough and it's well done like everything else. The game is probably a bit more puzzle-platformer than action(so far.. and I should say there's plenty of platform jumping, swinging, and hand/eye coordination stuff.. you just aren't constantly fighting enemies the entire time too), but the puzzles are great.. not unrealistically impossible, but they require some thought and dexterity and they continue to get more challenging the further you go. In every aspect, this is one of my most satisfying purchases. And by the way, if you try the demo and like the concept, but aren't sure if there's enough to it, you gain more abilities and everything gets SO much cooler as you get further in. The wizard can create more boxes and also platforms(and there's still 4 more ability slots I don't know what they do... that's 4 for EACH character, and I think 5 more for the thief), the warrior gets a charge ability(and 3 or 4 more I don't have yet) and you get various special items for even more abilities, customization, and bonuses.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Trine is basically a platformer with some minor puzzle elements. You will be jumping around on said platforms quite a lot, but instead of having just one character, you have three, which you can change on the fly (unless one or more of them died) and also has his own set of skills. The mage can conjure crates, planks and a floaty triangle thingies, the thief has a grappling hook and a bow and the knight is best suited for combat, but the thief is pretty much the best class, mostly because of her grappling hook, which you will most likely use extensively. It's also great to just circumvent the few "puzzles" you get in the game.Her bow is also a great weapon, even in close combat, unless you are overwhelmed by enemies.And now let's talk about those enemies, shall we?Skeletons. Tons of 'em. Not running around in the levels, no, they're spawning. Again and again. And that is nothing more than annoying and certainly not fun. Sometimes I've felt like in Call of Duty, when you aren't moving forwards and enemies just keep spawning and spawning...You will also encounter bats from time to time, which are also quite annoying, but at least they're not as common as those skeletons...All in all a good and quite nice looking game with some annoyances here and there.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												A fun game, with minor RPG elements, wonderful art style and visuals , albeit slightly repetitive gameplay and lack of character depth.The first thing about this game is the amazing visuals. It is a pleasure to play simply to look at the environment. The detail to the characters, spells, enemies and background art is great. The voiceover of the characters is also very well done. All in all, the production and art, design elements are top notch.The gameplay mechanics are well done - but the areas that could have been improved are the RPG elements. The gear and skills for each character are fairly irrelevant. It doesn't seem to be much of a stretch to say you could ignore all the gear and all the skills and finish the game without notice that you didn't use anything. They are merely small accents to your character - which is cool - but feels like it could have been developed more to make each character even more specialized and the party dynamic more rich.  As it stood, I used the fighter all the time and only switched to the mage when I needed a box and the thief when I needed to swing (and maybe at least half the time I could just make boxes to achieve the same ends).  This wasn't enough to detract from the fun of the game - it just had me thinking there was a lot of character overlap or lack of puzzle diversity to properly utilize each character more.Leading to the "puzzles" - each level, each map was essentially always the same type. Eventually you get slightly different obstacles such as spinning boards, button pushing, but most of the time it was "jump, make a box, jump, make a box, (maybe swing)".  More diversity in this area would have enhanced things. Same with the story. I don't put much weight into the story, but it could have also been a lot more interesting than it ultimately turns out to me. It was only 10 hours in length for me, and I don't play very fast, so expect others could go through even faster.With that said, it was still a very fun game. Recommended if on sale for sure.  I have bought the 2nd game (as a testament to the enjoyment of the first) and hope some of the things above are more fleshed out making it really what it could be. Then if things go well, onto the 3rd installment.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Quick review:Short Verdict: One of the best games I've ever played! It's a mix of all the genres I love: RPG, puzzle, platformer, exploration, and it also has some fighting. I've loved it so much I beat it twice in a row! I started playing the Original Game (OG), which was amazing, then I moved to Enchanted Edition (EE), which was even better (if you wanna play the game just once, go for EE, although playing both might be worth, since they still feel slightly like different games). I'll definitely play Trine 2 when I have the chance! (Note: I haven't tried playing it online, so I can't comment on that)Pros: Great balanced mix of different game genres Beautiful graphics Awesome BGM Three different interchangeable characters who are likeable and have their unique set of upgradable skills 15+1 long and well-planned distinct levels with their own atmosphere and a lot of secrets to find Collectible equipment to further customize your characters Really addicting, it doesn't get old even if you're replaying a level Nice voice acting, especially the narrator's Even though the game is old, the devs are still responsive at the forums, especially after EE, I guessCons: Zoya, the Thief, is a bit overpowered I wish there was more to the story--I thought it was a bit shallow and I wanted more A bit easy for me, even on hard (haven't tried the OG-exclusive Very Hard Mode though) (OG ONLY!) Moving objects is slower than needed to be (a lot faster on EE) (OG ONLY!) Conjuring objects with the controller is a pain (improved on EE) (OG ONLY!) Bats are really annoying and seem a bit broken (they've been removed from EE)Bought on / for: Humble Store for US$ 0.99. But it's definitely worth the full price they're asking for!

												Verdict: Why haven't you bought this already?!This game has just had a completely free, absolutely stunning graphics upgrade, and co-op multi-player added where it originally had none, 5 years after original release, FOR FREE. Let this sink in for a moment, in this day and age of nickle&diming for worthless trinket pixel additions or triple A pricing for practically untouched re-releases. If you already own this, it is worth reinstalling and playing all over again; if you don't own it, it's worth every penny.At the current sales price of 80-90% off for ALL Frozenbytes games (Trine 1&2 and Shadowgrounds), you really should just stop reading this and go buy whatever parts your collection is missing, right now. In fact, buy copies for all your friends. This company needs encouragement, and their success needs to be a bright beacon of enlightenment for games developers and publishers out there.There's free demos to all their games if you're still doubting. Its unique experience is best understood through direct gameplay anyway. Get it, play it, then tell me again this isn't worth paying for.Btw, performance tip: if you use the enchanted version with an NVidia GPU, make sure to add the trine1_32bit.exe file to the NVidia control panel under Manage 3D Settings, otherwise even though it uses the same engine as Trine 2, you will get a lot worse performance. The enchanted executable is in a subdirectory of the main Trine game folder. Doing this with the free downloadable nvidiaInspector and adding to the predefined Trine 2 profile is probably the best way to take advantage of the optimizations for the updated engine.

The narrator fits the tone of the game quite well which also makes it fairly entertaining. This game also has the very elusive Box Wizard! Yes, you heard it here first folks, there is a Box Wizard. He is a professional Boxer in a sense that he can summon boxes! He can also summon some other stuff, but who cares about that when you have freaking boxes?!?!The story of the game is also pretty enjoyable, making it a great game to unwind to. So, if you want to adventure as a Thief, Knight, and a Box Wizard, the Trine series is perfect for you. If you're not sure if you want to get into this game, I'd still give it a go, you never know, you might enjoy crushing your enemies under some boxes.Side note, this game is so awesome that it thanked coffee in the end credits!

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												A fun game, with minor RPG elements, wonderful art style and visuals , albeit slightly repetitive gameplay and lack of character depth.The first thing about this game is the amazing visuals. It is a pleasure to play simply to look at the environment. The detail to the characters, spells, enemies and background art is great. The voiceover of the characters is also very well done. All in all, the production and art, design elements are top notch.The gameplay mechanics are well done - but the areas that could have been improved are the RPG elements. The gear and skills for each character are fairly irrelevant. It doesn't seem to be much of a stretch to say you could ignore all the gear and all the skills and finish the game without notice that you didn't use anything. They are merely small accents to your character - which is cool - but feels like it could have been developed more to make each character even more specialized and the party dynamic more rich.  As it stood, I used the fighter all the time and only switched to the mage when I needed a box and the thief when I needed to swing (and maybe at least half the time I could just make boxes to achieve the same ends).  This wasn't enough to detract from the fun of the game - it just had me thinking there was a lot of character overlap or lack of puzzle diversity to properly utilize each character more.Leading to the "puzzles" - each level, each map was essentially always the same type. Eventually you get slightly different obstacles such as spinning boards, button pushing, but most of the time it was "jump, make a box, jump, make a box, (maybe swing)".  More diversity in this area would have enhanced things. Same with the story. I don't put much weight into the story, but it could have also been a lot more interesting than it ultimately turns out to me. It was only 10 hours in length for me, and I don't play very fast, so expect others could go through even faster.With that said, it was still a very fun game. Recommended if on sale for sure.  I have bought the 2nd game (as a testament to the enjoyment of the first) and hope some of the things above are more fleshed out making it really what it could be. Then if things go well, onto the 3rd installment.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Trine is a delightfully charming platformer that is fun to play both by yourself and with others. Both playthroughs I enjoyed.Pros:- Absolutely gorgeous world! The colors are amazing, everything looks crisp, and the whole game looked mystical. - I like the switching through characters. Every character has his or her own abilities, and they are all distinct. Playing as each character is a different experience and way of getting from A to B.- Solid character controlling for the most part. I appreciate any side scrolling game with a good idea on how jumping and moving around should feel. No awkwardness here.- Playing this game made me happy. I don't know how else to explain it.Cons:- Sometimes the game would freeze. That's never fun.- The drawing button for the wizard and the move objects button should be different! Ahh! The only button mapping that bugged me.- The segments at the beginning of the levels are dumb. You stare at a map while you wait for the narrator to finish speaking. Very rarely do narrators in a video game work.- Come to think of it, the voice acting in general was meh.- Was that even a story?- What is the point of mana? The meter would decrease but never enough to make me think "man I wish I had more mana" because there are checkpoints frequently.- I wish it was longer!  One playthrough lasts about 4 hours or so, longer if you want to level all the way up.The downsides for Trine are definitely there, but they weren't significant enough to make me dislike this game or not want to play anymore. Trine is worth it for the stunning visuals and the fun gameplay with friends I'd say. I never played this game thinking eek when is this going to end. I didn't want it to end!There are no jump scares, only pretty things to look at.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Relaxing, easy to get into and very fluently working platform/physics-puzzler. Gorgeous, colorful background/art design (it's a really great looking game). Not very difficult, but there are a few more tricky obstacles. You control one out of three, instantly switchable characters with different abilities to navigate the levels, manipulate it's objects, create your own or fight enemies. These three characters have some personality, but you don't get to know much of their backgrounds and they remain stereotypes mostly:- Charming, lady-lover wizard who conjures boxes, planks and platforms. Kills enemies with physics.- Mysterious, reserved thief who uses a grappling hook to pull and swing herself around. Kills enemies with bow.- Overweight knight and wannabe hero who likes food and drinking. Uses shield to avoid damage. Kills enemies with sword.The story leaves to be desired. There is one, there is a narrator speaking before each level and the characters sometimes comment things too. But it's your generic good vs evil fantasy thing. There is a name-giving "Trine" artifact binding the souls of the three characters together. It sounded interesting first, but it's not worked out further, it's only a tool to give reason why these otherwise very different personalities come together for an adventure, and creates the outline of it.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												It's been almost two years since I played the sequel (Trine 2) to this game (Trine).  But, when I saw they had updated Trine to the Trine Enchanted Edition by porting it to the same engine used in Trine 2, I jumped at the chance to buy it.  I'm very pleased.  Just like Trine 2, the graphics, sound, and game play are all excellent.  The amazing thing about my liking this game is that I pretty much hate platforming games.  Yet, this is, indeed, a side-scrolling platformer.  The difference is that Trine (and Trine 2) aren't "twitch" based platformers.  In general, you have plenty of time to examine the area and can consider the platforming aspect to be part of the puzzle solving aspect of the game.  My only serious complaint with the game is that the last level (and the hidden level that unlocks after you finish that last level) is pure, twitchy, time-limited platforming.  It's frustrating.  But, considering that this is just one level (or two, if you count the bonus level) out of 16, I can live with it.  Plus, considering that I got a tad more than 20 hours of really fun gameplay (getting to that 100% Achiement level), I'd say Trine is definitely worth the price.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Remember "The Lost Vikings" from 1992?  By the company famous for the massively successful online multiplayer RPG franchise, "Rock 'n Roll Racing"?No?  Where you alive back then?  If not, then you have a temporary excuse.  Before you continue reading this review, go to your nearest second-hand video game retailer and steal either a Super Nintendo or a time machine.  If you stole the Super Nintendo, then also steal a copy of "The Lost Vikings", and play it through to the end.  If you stole a time machine, travel back to about 1984 and beg your parents to get it on a little earlier than scheduled so you can get a copy of "The Lost Vikings" for your eighth birthday.  Now that you know what to do, you have no more excuses.  Go.  When you're done playing through the game, come back.  I'll be waiting.If you were alive in 1992, your only excuse is that you are an ignorant person.  That is not a real excuse, but I forgive you for your ignorance.  You can follow the same steps as the person who was not alive in 1992, but be careful--don't trip over your ignorance, or do something stupid while back in 1986 like betting all your money on the Red Sox.Alright.  Done playing through "The Lost Vikings"?  "Trine" is a lot like that.  Slightly different abilities for your "Vikings", and much better graphics, but for the most part, it's the same idea.  Perhaps what makes it a little worse is that there are typically many glitchy solutions to individual puzzles (most involving either making a bunch of platforms with the wizard, or worm-jumping with the theif's grappling hook).What, never heard of worm-jumping?  Were you alive/competent in 1997?  See the above paragraphs, and replace "The Lost Vikings" with "Worms 2".  You'll thank me.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Wow, I can't believe I haven't said anything about Trine yet.On top of that - what? This game has ANY negative reviews? Wtf?Trine. This is one of the most breathtaking, fantastic games I have seen in the past decade. It's just stunning. The graphics are incredible, the physics based stuff is all hugely entertaining, and I find obliterating skeletons to be immensely satisfying. It's just fun. I enjoyed going back to levels and redoing them time and again to find stuff I missed, because they were just that good. I play with mouse n keyboard, naturally, so I didn't really have any issues with my controls. I can't imagine trying to play Trine with a DS3 or Xbox controller.Zoya is my favourite, naturally, Amadeus is my least favourite. Being a wizard is nice and all, but he really only exists to make boxes, for the most part. And you can end up making a -lot- of boxes. But, yeah. Pontius is okay too, and his hammer is AMAZING. It's awesome to see everything on the screen explode.I never really had any issues with the difficulty. It's fun enough just going through the game. The story is, when you really think about it, quite plain - essentially, skeletons appeared, and then three random heroes touched a thing called the Trine and became one in a way. But I still love it. It's just so quaint, and gives me a warm happy feeling inside. What's better than a story about knights in shining armor (and his thief companion, and the cowardly wizard guy who followed them about)?This game has no real elongated cutscenes or anything. It's just a simple platformer. You jump around the level, and hopefully you're the thief and you abuse the hell out of your grappling hook. The grappling hook is in my opinion one of the best parts of this game. It's just way too much fun to swing about with.The soundtrack is amazing. It's just amazing. The tone of the game is perfectly in harmony with what you're seeing, and it always feels appropriate. Each level has it's own theme. I love it.And the last level... I loved it. It was extremely challenging the first time, but that's great! I actually felt challenged, properly, not just because the devs had a range of multipliers for enemy HP and damage (which the game has anyway, but I played on hard nonetheless) but also because on this last level, the 'AI' drops stuff in front of you as you're going up this tower. If you're not fast enough, the lava rising with you gets you. It took me several tries to beat the first time, but it's absolutely just a measure of skill, even now when I'm out of practice I bet I could go back and complete again, easy. It's just about learning.I can't recommend this game enough. Some people complained that the levels aren't varied enough, but honestly I disagree. You're not just wandering around a castle, there's quite a variety of beautiful areas to get through, and I feel like each level has it's own set of things that distinguishes it from the other levels, they really don't all feel the same to me at all. Would you say Super Mario isn't varied enough, because you just go from one end of the level to the other, platforming along the way? No, you wouldn't.In short, Trine is an amazing game, especially at the price. It's on sale for as low as $1.50 so frequently you can set your watch by it. I think I remember this game being only $10 at one point, I don't really remember them raising it, but, hey, I'd pay $15 for it again if I knew beforehand how much enjoyment I would get from it.

Posted: December 21, 2015
												I'm starting to think physics games are doomed to fail for either not being realistic, or being too realistic. Trine somehow manages to combine both, in the worst way.The good:-Beautiful designs and backgrounds-Decent narrative-The mix of characters sometimes work well and are all utilised in finishing levels-When the physics does work, it's very satisfyingThe bad:-The narrative is often infuriatingly interrupted by things in-game, and then not continued until the next stage-The movement of characters, enemies, and objects is all much much too sloppy and often seems like everything's on ice, and covered in oil, making precision nigh on impossible-The physics doesn't work 90% of the timeThe game is actually impressive in how annoying it is, maybe because it has so potential that it fails to harness.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Trine is a story-telling puzzle and platformer game that I enjoyed very much in the gameplay and coop aspect. While I want to give this game my whole-hearted recommendation, I had to hesitate because I found that the game failed in the story-telling department. The first thing you notice when you start the game is the stunningly beautiful graphics which help set up this mystical atmosphere that just makes you eager to play the game. Because of that, I also grew a high expectation from the story. Sadly, as you progress through the game you start to realise that the story is almost... non-existent, in addition to a very anti-climatic and disappointing finale. I will say though, that at least the puzzles and platforming provided a decent challenge and that it was overall a pretty fun game.So the question is, is the game worth buying? Yes, but not at the full price. It's definitely something worth trying if you like platforming and/or playing a good coop game with friends.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Interesting puzzles and good atmosphere make for a pleasant experience. I can't say too much about the story since I just couldn't get into it. The 'leveling' seems a bit slapped on and doesn't really add too much since you're effectively railroaded into it anyway; same could be said about the inventory. These things and the occasional focus on fighting things just don't seem to fit very well. Some skellie killing is all well and good, throwing a boss into a puzzle room is much fun, but the times when you're screen locked into fighting 1by1 spawning is weird for this kind of game.As for the co-op... Honestly it's way easier to do yourself. And the level doesn't change with multiple people so it's completely unnecessary to have the other person. If anything you're just slowing each other down. I would not recommend this as a good co-op for those looking for a challenging puzzle game to play together. For just horsing around, sure.Trine is not a bad game, but I wouldn't list it as the most amazing/best platformer of its time. It's interesting, a little different, and could be something to do for a little while.

Posted: January 16, 2016
												When asked to describe my thoughts about Trine, only one word comes to mind.NOPE!I was shocked, literally shocked when I viewed the review of this game. One after another kept saying it is good.But it's so far from the truth.When one delves deeper into the depths of Trine one might not come back the same as he once was.Trine shares a common trait with certain platformers, for instance you must collect certain items each level to get that perfect score. Yet most levels require several playthroughs before you can finish them 100%, not that it's bad.But when you come to a certain point where you needed to jump slightly instead of running off of it, and that wasn't the first time you forgot it either, comes frustration. And as I was playing things just kept adding up.The story was pure horribleness, the attempt at humour was even worse, the wizard is the most annoying character in the game, once the thief is dead you might as well restart the level seeing as most levels requires her to finish.The items are terrible, I can't remember if I ever found something for the wizard, not that I would care to either but there's a certain principle of things.The enemies are pure moronic, they will either try to kill you with a wall between you and him. Or just casually walk off a cliff trying to get to you. Bats are only there to rid you of your health, a lazy enemy at best.This game is stupid, I don't know why nor would I be able to comprehend anyone that likes this.My joy was killed at the beginning of the game, and the horrors of 2player mode (control-wise) ensured me that I would never be playing this again.Also, why does this game have or even need 2 sequels, I can think of at least several things that could've benefited from all the money and time that went into their creation. Like planting a tree or stepping on my balls so I would've been midly distracted when hearing such news.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												It's too bad there's no button for "it depends."Trine has a few things going for it. The visuals are charming - the characters and the background have a distinctive, beautiful fantasy-world feel to them. The controls are tight - you will have a lot of fun with all 3 of your characters, playing them in 3 different ways to jump around the levels and defeat the baddies.The main downsides of this game are two. First of all, it's just not challenging. I'm not sure if this game was trying to be a puzzle platformer but it falls down on both the puzzling and the platforming. In terms of puzzles, nothing really confuses you for more than a few breaths. Exploiting the physics of the game to move around the levels is usually how it's done but gets old after awhile. The story is also lacking. It's entirely non-descript. This may be a non-issue for some, especially given the short length of the game, but along with the lack of challenge this meant it got boring by the end of my four hour playtime.If you're particularly intrigued by the concept of this game or you find a great sale, go for it! It's a fun little romp. If you're looking for a bit more depth, look elsewhere!

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Did I really just write a whole review about what I hated about Trine, copy it to clipboard, and then accidentally lose it copying the lyrics of Supertramp's "The Logical Song" into a review for Chantelise?Yeah. I did.Anyway, this game starts out with the neat idea of a puzzle/adventure game - which seemed to impress a lot of people when it came out - only to stop being creative halfway through and produce a game with the audacity of a day-old gumwad. Stop playing halfway through - I guarantee you did all the enjoyable parts already, the Knight's hammer isn't even that great, and the last level is one of those pseudo-timed lava-slowly-rising dealies. The controls turn out to be too sluggish and most obstacles are better solved with methods that feel like cheating, so the whole experience sort of just falls apart and feels half lazy and half frustratingly vindictive. Sliding off♥♥♥♥♥♥into hazards that were way off screen happens way too often in the late-game.Also the characters are idiotic tropes, the narration is predictable, cheesy, pointless, and even kind of wrong in a couple points ("and then they heard his voice" isn't really accurate if the only things he does is laugh), and the payoff at the end is just so embarassingly bad it should've been replaced with a big "YOU WON" sign. The graphical design is pretty nice in a lot of parts and only confuses you over what's actually something you can step on in a few parts, so that's, uh, positive. A big negative is that a lot of the music sounds like it belongs in a Geico commercial or a bad fantasy parody movie - or one of those off-budget CG movies that try to copy Dreamwork's titles to cash in on grandmas who want to buy their grandchildren a fun DVD but weren't paying enough attention to the ads. Although Netflix is picking up a lot of them now so I guess the irony factor is working out for them.Anyway, if you bought this on Humble Bundle for however close to almost free you wanted to get, fine, whatever, but probably save yourself the hassle and stop after three levels.If you bought it when it came out - thanks to your inflation of its popularity, they made a Trine 2, which I bought before actually playing through this tasteless ♥♥♥♥♥ack. So, thanks for that.

												This game is gorgeous, and also the core gameplay design is highly effective. You can switch the 3 characters at any given time if you are required to progress further in a level. And I mean that in a negative way. Nowadays, such platform and puzzle games are usually serious and hard to complete. But this one... it cannot be taken seriously, no way. And it isn't funny either. It is way too easy to complete, and the storytelling is so childish that you wanna scream. It has a hype surrounding it which I cannot tolerate. Get serious people. This game is a kitsch. I'll try Trine 2, who knows... I still have some spark of interest left. Maybe part 2 will be better.
