content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Having three characters in one was an original and worthy idea. However, in solo, that concept break down because of Zoya. Zoya has a grappling hook, that allows her to bypass most puzzles, and zoom accross levels. It's fun to stay in the air for a long time, but that doesn't provide for interesting challenges. Also, since she is also good in combat, she makes Pontius optional, and since Amadeus is so limited, he too is almost optional.The game is obviously meant to be played in coop, so that each character's weaknesses must be compensated by the other's strenghts. You wouldn't be able to zoom accross the level with Zoya, because you would have to find way for Pontius and Amadeus to cross the obstacles. However, I haven't had an opportunity to try that, so i can't tell you if that actually works.However, regardless of whether you liked this game, I do recommend Trine 2, which is awesome in all regards.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2013
												Oh god, Trine is one of the most boring and monotonous games I've ever played. It really doesn't get much more trivial than this for a platformer, even Super Mario Bros. has more variety and little unnecessary filler.The AI is dumb and will constantly fall off ledges and jump back up, only to fall off again. Weapons are slow and inaccurate, the wizard's conjuration ability requires such precision that it becomes useless in any combat situation. Also, why can't I jump and fire arrows or use my conjuration spells in the air? Stupid limitations.The premise is interesting, the Trine mechanics are innovative, albeit contrived. The story is lacklustre. The narration during the loading screens is so slow and fragmented that I can't be bothered waiting to hear what's being told.The levels are all too similar in layout and lack inspiration. The puzzle mechanics aren't challenging and are too predictable, they seem to be the only reason for the physics engine to exist in the first place.Co-op is almost unplayable and seemed tacked on "just because" as both players control one of three characters, but only have access to two of the characters at a time, which slows down gameplay considerably. It also doesn't make sense in context with the Trine itself. The option for three player co-op is there but I'm not certain many people would be able to take advantage of this on PC.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Mediocre.This game seems to suffer from an identity crisis? What is it? Quoting the manual, "Trine is a great platformer game for the modern era infused with action and puzzle elements"Well, I'm afraid it doesn't do any of these particularly well.The jumping is sloppy, and you never really feel confident in landing in any particular spot. The game's physics are sloppy. Very frequently I found myself trying to "brute force" my way through jumps, especially when landing on platforms which are affected by the mass upon them (such as beams which pivot around their centre).The puzzles are based on the physics engine, and quite often involve using the Wizard to move/create blocks and planks to get somewhere. However, this is often sloppy. It feels more like you're 'guiding' blocks around, careful not to knock down any towers you have built to get anywhere, as the thing you are dragging rotates unpredictably, rather than firmly dragging them around. I suppose it fits thematically, as it is telekenesis, but from a gameplay point of view, the player doesn't feel in control. Furthermore, it usually takes a few tries to create what you want, particularly with the square blocks or triangular floating platforms (which rotate and are very unstable)Combat is plain awful. There are four main enemy types in the game, and they're all skeletons with varying abilities. You'll be seeing them throughout the whole game. What's worse is that they just keep spawning. One can spend several minutes just whacking them, as more keep spawning in, with no indication on how long until they stop spawning. You don't have a very varied move set either. It's either hold up your shield and wait for an opening with the knight, shoot an arrow at them with the theif (who cannot fire in mid-air) or hit them with a heavy object, usually with the wizard (who can't move when creating objects/using telekenesis). Enemy AI is also poor, trying to scramble over ledges, waves of monsters continually walking into a situation where they crush themselves. I admit, I played this on easy, but as far as I'm aware it only changes damage given and taken, rather than gameplay or AI.So, to give some positives, the environments are very detailed, music is fine, dialogue has some witty moments, even if the story is unmemorable.

Posted: August 31, 2014
												Trine is an action/puzzle platformer with 3 types of heroes, 2 types of bosses and 1 type of level.The graphics are pretty gorgeous, but unfortunately for the gameplay it's not great. There is quite a mess on screen and it's sometimes hard to tell a bonus pickup from an enemy attack.The controls - which should be the most important thing for a platformers - don't allow for enough precision and feel sloppy, which will often trigger misses. Not that it matters because the game is too easy anyway.All the levels feel exactly the same, beyond level 1 there is hardly any new mechanics, from there it's just grinding your way through. The fixed camera placement is annoying. You know objects are there but the camera won't budge or allow you to place objects outside the current field of vision.There are just 2 bosses, they're not epic, just merely a slightly tougher foe, and they come back several times in later levels.Not much variety in enemies either, it's just the same skeletons from the beginning to the end.All in all, this is just like playing the same level 15 times over again, with a different backdrop.I can appreciate some may be drawn by the medieval fantasy storytelling or by the luxurious backdrops. The graphics got overhauled recently with the enchanted edition and it's quite superb. One can wish the gameplay had got improved instead!

Posted: April 21, 2014
												I bought this when it was on sale for about a dollar so I didn't expect much of it. Instead, what I got was one heck of a puzzle platformer that's simply drop-dead gorgeous. The game itself is simple enough for anyone to pick-up but the platforming and puzzles later on can be very challenging but the feeling of satisfaction you get from finishing those puzzle-platforming sections is just bliss.The way the game is presented is very much like a story-book with the narrator, the cutscenes and those amazing setpieces. You can seriously take a screenshot of any section of this game and it'd look like a painting worth being framed and hung on someone's lounge room!In single player, you can play as one character, either as the mage, the thief or the knight; each with their own strengths and weaknesses and you are allowed to switch as whichever character you want in order to get through a particular puzzle or platforming section. For example, the mage can conjure boxes and platforms to help you with puzzles and getting to places but is pretty useless when it comes to battle while the knight can lift heavy objects and is the main fighting force when it comes to battles. This interesting mechanic has been implemented extremely well within each level as you will be encouraged to play as all of the different classes in order to get through it and that makes for an already enjoyable game all the more enjoyable!All in all, Trine is an amazing-looking game with fantastic gameplay to boot and if it ever goes on sale again, don't hesitate and dive right in!

That doesn't mean you won't have a great time playing it alone. The gameplay flows very smoothly and has a very fluent control so you won't die by choppy, unfair deaths.The Music in the games is fantastic and beautiful which you can listen to over and over again, so I highly recommend getting the Soundtrack And Art with the games. 												A pretty physics-based platform/puzzle game. The main gimmick is the ability to switch between three protagonists. The wizard can levitate items and summon platforms and blocks. The thief can shoot arrows and use a grappling hook to swing and climb. And the knight can block with his shield and swing his sword.The game mechanics suggest that the three protagonists should be used almost equally, but the thief quickly becomes the most useful character. Her arrow spam quickly eclipses the sword as the fastest, most versatile and the safest way to kill the nearly-infinitely respawning skeletons. And her agility and the grappling hook negates many (but not all) puzzles that would have required the wizard.Oh, and the final level even makes this core problem more apparent. It's a timed climb to the top of a tower while an enemy sorcerer summons objects to hinder your way. Even if you already know how the completely scripted event goes, you're still going to need the thief to keep up with the climb.

Posted: December 12, 2013
												Great little platformer game, especially with its awesome artwork. The story starts out pretty good, but seemingly loses its point before the end of the game, which is unfortunate. Thankfully, the controls are smooth and work well with a keyboard. The ability to use all three characters to your advantage is an interesting feature, as they each have their own strengths and weaknesses. Although, I would say Zoya (The Thief) is the go-to character as it is much easier to navigate with the use of her grapple hook. Pontius (The Knight) is great for dispatching groups of enemies at a time, especially bats once you gain access to a ground smash later in the game. Amadeus (The Mage) is able to fully skip a majority of the puzzles once fully upgraded and with heavy use of his spawned crates and planks, which is nice if you've been through the game once over. I wouldn't particuarly say the game has much replay value though beyond a second runthrough on Very Hard (If achievements and harder difficulties are your thing) as it does not have anything else to offer except being able to play with all of your previously acquired upgrades. There were also a few times that I encountered my use of attacks not actually working as they should which became a bit of nuisance. Overall, I would recommend the game to someone if they are looking for a platformer to waste a bit of time on. The game has its own feel to the genre because of the use of three characters, so it's not inherently like any other platformer that comes to mind. It is worth its price point, but is even better if you are able to get it on sale in the package along with its sequel.

												"Charming" is probably the single best word to describe this side-scrolling puzzle-platformer. Attractive graphics and a great soundtrack highlight a strong physics system that makes the way you solve its puzzles the focus, rather than the solutions themselves. Fans of super hard platformers a la Meat Boy and those hoping for extremely complex puzzle elements will likely be disappointed with the relatively low level of difficulty. The lack of combat depth and variety of enemies are the game's weakest points, but it knows its limits and doesn't spend too much time on either. If you're looking for a responsive game that allows you to utilize your own creativity in solving its puzzles, this is a must buy.

												Imagine if Dungeons & Dragons, Portal, Super Mario Brothers 3, and Donkey Kong Country all got thrown into a blender and set to an epic orchesta score written by Harry Gregson Williams and the result would be Trine. The story is on the level of depth as Mario (i.e. princess captured, go save) but you'll hear no complaint out of me. The actions flow seemlessly, weapon upgrades acutally progress at the same rate as the difficulty curve, and you'll keep coming back so you can find everything.  This is the best $20 you'll spend on a game this year, promise.

Posted: April 5, 2016
												It takes a lot of skill to make a game that plays just as well, if not better, co-operatively as it does with just a single player.  Trine excels in both situations.Whereas the Shadowgrounds series was dark and broody, Trine is almost its exact opposite.  This game is bright, vibrant, and colorful.  The fairy-tale fantasy world you’ll be exploring is full of beautiful detail.  Wooden planks will creak under your weight, flowing lava will bubble and spurt menacingly, and leaves will rustle in the wind as you run by.  The story here is simplistic, but well-told by a very good narrator, who almost sounds as if he is reading you a bedtime story.  The three characters you control have their own endearing personalities, and it is easy to become attached to them throughout the adventure.When a Thief, a Wizard, and a Knight all happen across the same ancient artifact, it binds their souls together into one.  They now are forced to travel together in order to figure out what is causing the undead plague ravaging the kingdom.  The journey consists mostly of platforming and combat, with precious experience potions and treasure chests hidden behind devious traps and puzzles.  You will need to utilize all three characters’ strengths in order to succeed, as they are each very unique.  The Thief can grapple to any wooden surface and swing through the air, allowing you to quickly skip huge sections of a level.  The Wizard can create boxes, and then planks, and then platforms, by drawing shapes in the air with your mouse.  The Knight is a master of combat, and can also use his huge hammer to break or shove objects.  Each character is unique and useful in different situations, and as a single player you’ll be able to switch between them freely.But the game really shines when you add two more people to the mix.  Then you all play at the same time, but you are locked into your specific character.  A gap that was simple for the Thief to simply swing right over becomes a devious puzzle for the more land-bound Knight.  The difficulty really ramps up when you cannot just carry each character along, and that is great.  You really have to communicate and work through the solutions together with your partners, and the game tends to go slower as a result, but it feels more rewarding.  This is the ideal way to play the game, and the systems here really shine when you master them along with two other adventurers.The soundtrack supports the game really well, and you can tell that Frozenbyte’s Ari Pulkkinen has improved his skills over time.  The plucky, etherial soundtrack lends itself well to the fairy tale aesthetic of the game, and is backed up well by truly outstanding voice acting.  The aforementioned Narrator is a welcome companion on your quest, introducing each stage and major event that leads to the final showdown.Yet the visuals are easily the standout quality of this game.  Just look at these screenshots, and imagine how alive everything feels!  (Even though you’re surrounded by undead skeletons)  The backgrounds are vibrant and full of detail.  Every level feels unique and different setpieces are always being introduced.  From a dragon graveyard to a twisted forest, from the depths of an abandoned mine to an ancient temple; no two levels look the same.Trine is a great game.  The completionist in me loved searching for every experience potion and hidden treasure chest on every stage, working my way through these well-crafted puzzles.  The last level has a bit of a ridiculous difficulty spike compared to the rest of the game, but I’ll forgive that minor quibble.  This game gave me a dozen hours or so of beautiful platforming action.

TL;DRTrine Enchanted Edition is a well paced game with great visuals and performance, enchanting atmosphere and narrative, but with a sometimes lacklustre and repetitive soundtrack with puzzles that leave more to be desired.ReviewThe GoodTrine Enchanted Edtion, is a 2D Puzzle Platformer that has a rather bewitching feeling to it.The narrative (literally) is given by a warm, booming voice that provides a charismatic experience when playing.The story itself can be dull at times; being predictable to some sense with your typical heroes and villains.The accompanying soundtrack fits the game extremely well, but feels repeated or too similar to the other soundtracks in the game and can become dull. Take this with a grain of salt, because while some exceptional game soundtracks can be very noticeable for good reasons, the majority of the time you are focusing on the gameplay.However, the graphics/art style is a completely different story. With what one might consider a rather charming design, Trine Enchanted Edition has impressed me with what looks like a very imaginative design. Whether you are speedrunning or stopping for a second to edit your inventory, nearly every single menu and environment you are in looks incredible.The BadHowever, Trine has its flaws.Aside from the sometimes predictable story and repetitive soundtrack, there are a few more personal ticks.Coming from CSGO, where I can skip through menus by spamming the escape key or the enter key, isn't the case in Trine.During loading/story cutscenes, there is the option to skip the scene or click a start button when it has ended.By instinct I press the enter key, but that doesn't do anything and I have to specifically click a tiny button in the lower middle of the screen.This becomes really frustrating sometimes, especially when I'm busy taking a sip of a drink or something and just want to start the next area without having to put down my drink.Yet again, take this with a grain of salt as these are personal gripes and do not affect the gameplay itself and will likely not affect many people.After going through all of these elements and shortcomings of Trine Enchanted Edition, it is still an enjoyable and solid game to play.The ScoreOverall, I give this game a well earned 7.5/10

Posted: January 15, 2014
												Trine is a side scrolling platform game in which you play three protaganists a wizard, a thief and a soldier, whose souls have somehow been gathered together by the Trine. To complete game you need to complete the levels, collecting experience to gain better weapons or skills is of use you do this be collecting bottles that are laying around or hidden, or by killing monsters and collecting the experience. Also lying around are energy bottles to top up your energy which the wizard seems to use a great deal more than the other characters (at least in the levels I have played any how.)The idea pf three souls together  has the benefit that you can swap at anytime between the different characters if one character has a skill to solve that the others do not. This makes it interesting as you move between them to complete the different levels. So soon learn which character is best for the upcoming task. For me the Graphics make it stand out, the environment is beautifully drawn which makes it a real pleasure to play. There is a great deal of jumping about and I sometimes find it hard to control using the keyboard; especially the thief when she is trying to get onto a platform from the grappling rope. I think a game controller would  make it a bit easier, I am going to try this to see if is indeed true. The default movement controls are the standard WASD controls perhaps if you wish to use the keyboard to play, redefining the keys could also improve things.Another positive aspect of the game is the narration which makes you feel you are creating the book as you go along. The music also adds to the atmosphere quite well.During the hours I've played I've lost a character because they ran out of health many, many times. If you feel you wish to start over. You can choose from the menu to either start from the last checkpoint or restart the level. Restarting from the last checkpoint doesn't reset the monsters and puzzles that you've completed whilst restarting the level does reset the puzzles and monsters. However collected experience is retained by you upon the restart so during the restart you will only see the experience you haven't collected, so far.I thoroughly recommend Trine and I will continue with Trine2 once I've completed Trine.

Posted: October 9, 2015
												This is an absolutely brilliant game for a casual multiplayer session with a couple of friends.First of all, I'm not sure I'd play it singleplayer, as the storyline is lacklustre (something about magic and an ancient artefact, I think) and the gameplay laborious. but add another player and that's where it really shines. It plays like a platformer/puzzler hybrid and two or three players combining the different abilities of the characters makes for endless fun.Secondly, play with an Xbox controller (or similar). The keyboard/mouse controls are not so great, but it's really fluid with a controller - and this is coming from a PC gamer who has almost never used a gamepad.Essentially this game has you (and/or your friends) as a wizard (with abilities to conjour boxes etc), a knight (with a sword and magical shield) and a thief (with a grappling hook and bow). All of these abilities are well bnalanced, and you will find yourself having to use all three characters as you work around the puzzles in your way. There might be any number of solutions to a given puzzle, so it's worth trying all the characters.Finally, this game has recieved a graphical overhaul and looks absolutely beautiful. The 'theme' is a very colourful fairytale look, with locations from enchanted forests with colourful flowers, giant leaves and massive snails to underground caverns with glowing crystals and bottomless pits. It's essentially a 2.5D game (3D animation in a 2D plane), but don't let that put you off - the backgrounds and lighting are very impressive.Definitely a 9/10 - loses the one point for the weak storyline and crazy boss level, but it's still a really fun game. Definitely worth picking up.

Posted: June 25, 2016
												TL:DR an enjoyable casual platformer that should give you a few hours of funThis is a pretty enjoyable casual side scrolling platformer where you can switch between 3 different characters at the press of a button. The 3 characters are the knight, wizard and thief with each having different abilities. The knight has a sword for attacking enemies and can block attacks and projectiles from enemies and traps. The wizard can move objects like blocks and crates using magic as well as summon crates and bridges. The thief has a bow and arrow for attacking and a grappling hook to swing with. The level design is great and encourages you to make full use of all 3 characters and their abilities. The games levels look beautiful as well.Good points:- i like the idea of having the 3 characters with different abilties and the levels give you plenty of oppurtunity to make use of them- the level design is great and with plenty of traps and puzzles to try and get past-the game isbeautiful to look atBad points:- there isnt much variety of enemy and bosses and they are generally pretty boring to fight. The regular enemies are just a case of bashing the attack button with the occasional block. With the bosses you get put in a small room with a big boss who will have a glowing area of their body you have to hit. Since your attacks dont do mch damage the bosses are a dull grind-The game has a story of sorts but it pretty generic and forgettable

Posted: August 27, 2015
												I highly recommend this game. I'm typically not "all that into" 2D platformers, but this game was a true gem, and an example of what a good 2D platoformer is. The story is enchanting (no pun intended :) ), althoguh not enthralling, the combat is good but not great, but the puzzles are what make this game standout. I loved the little challenges in-between the "skirmishes" with the undead, figuring out how to get over a hurdle (literally sometimes). I loved that the puzzles were very non-linear and you could brute force your way through them, or you could figure out a clever alternative :). It's pretty short (I only played 10 hours on easy- maybe longer on harder difficulties- I think the only difference is the amount of enemies spawned), but it's short and sweet. The replayability isn't too high, but I don't care so much to replay games, so that doesn't affect me. All-in-all, a charming short game with a lot of thought and care placed into it, and even if you don't generally like platoformers, I'd recommend giving it a try :).

Posted: December 20, 2015
												You know, I only bought into the series after seeing Trine 3 and thinking of how great this seemed. Maybe I'm one of the select few who looked at this and thought it was amazing. I've started the trilogy at the third game and even with the stupid and menial bugs/glitches I have seen, I would have to say that I really enjoy this game. My only complaint that I have is the length of the game. I feel like the story itself could have led to a much longer sequence, but I digress. I have enjoyed the concept and even though I have started at the last installment, I plan to venture into the previous games of the series. If, according to the reviews, this is the worst game of the trilogy, I look forward into heading backwards into the previous games. All in all, after seeing the value just in watching the trailer video for Trine 3, I bought into this series. It didn't take but a few minutes into this game that I have enjoyed the concept of Trine and looked forward to the depth and intrigue into this game. I can understand the feeling that there may have been a rush to push this third sequence, but for what it's worth I appreciate all aspects of this game. I would not rate this game a 10/10 in any means. but for the value of buying this trilogy on sale I feel the money is well spent. Even if you invest time into one of the games in this trilogy, it is money well spent. Long story short, do not over look this game due to the negative reviews. It's a great pick up for the sale value. Today 12/1/15 the trilogy is $15 of which I think Trine 3 is worth the value. Watch a let's play or a walkthrough before you count this game out for the mixed reviews. You wont be disappointed, unless you highly detest the type of game, not the story or value as a whole. It has been one of the few steam games that has kept my attention for longer than 5 minutes.Update 12/14:As of now, I have beaten Trine 3 and 1 and am finishing up Trine 2. After playing through, almost the entire series, I would have to say that Trine 3 is still, by far my favorite. Maybe it''s simply because I played 3 first. I'm not sure. I feel like the puzzles in 1 and 2 were much more easily to "cheat" through than 3. All in all I would recommend buying into the entire series. Good luck!Update 12/20:After making it through Trine 2 and entering into the DLC, I enjoyed the game, but with how long the DLC makes the game, I've felt like I was only playing it out of desire to finish, not enjoyment.  All in all they're all great games, but I still think I enjoyed 3 the most!

Posted: July 31, 2011
												One of the few rare titles where everything seems to fit together almost seamlessly. The graphical style is beautiful, the music is wonderfully enchanting, and the dialogue, while being light hearted, is performed to perfection. The puzzle mechanics are also intelligently designed, making clever use of the physics engine while keeping controls and combat relatively simple. Each character has a unique role to perform and you'll find yourself switiching characters often in order to fully utilise these roles.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												Trine is a side scroll platform game with heavy puzzle elements that takes place in a medieval fairytale fantasy world. You control three characters, each with different abilitities, skills and weapons and your goal is basically to reach the end of each level by solving the enviromental puzzles with at least of your characters alive . In order to solve the puzzles and overcome the various obstacles that you will be facing, you have to combine your characters' different abilitites effectively. The story follows a wizard, a knight and a thief that have been trapped by a magic artifact and have lost their descrete physical appearance. From now on, they can only coexist in one body each time but you can switch between them at any given moment. So they set on a journey to find information on how to break the spell and at the same time to free their kingdom from the evil dark powers that attacked it when the King died. The presentation is nothing less than top notch, The visuals are stunning, the last time I was this impressed with graphics was back in 2004 with Far Cry and a few years later with Crysis. From the art direction, the fluid motion of the characters and the backround theme of each level to the narration and the excellent soundtrack, everything is combined in harmony to produce this visual masterpiece.However, there are a few aspects that are on the dowside. I wouldn't say that the story is on the thin side, but I would prefer it if it was narrated a bit more seriously. By that I mean that the characters are given almost a comical tone which doesn't fit well with the overall theme of the story. As for the difficulty of the game, I found it extremely easy even on the hard level which was a surprise since this is a platformer. The puzzles were quite easy as well. The length of the game is also disputed by many, however I think it is fine, this way each level is memorable and distinguishable. If the game was bigger there would be a lot of unnecessary repetition for no reason, especially considering the short range of the gameplay diversity.All in all, Trine is a beautiful game with unforgettable art style and smooth mechanics that despite its' short lenght, it will travel you to a world of magic and beauty for a few hours. I can't wait to get my hands on Trine 2.

Posted: October 9, 2015
												This is an absolutely brilliant game for a casual multiplayer session with a couple of friends.First of all, I'm not sure I'd play it singleplayer, as the storyline is lacklustre (something about magic and an ancient artefact, I think) and the gameplay laborious. but add another player and that's where it really shines. It plays like a platformer/puzzler hybrid and two or three players combining the different abilities of the characters makes for endless fun.Secondly, play with an Xbox controller (or similar). The keyboard/mouse controls are not so great, but it's really fluid with a controller - and this is coming from a PC gamer who has almost never used a gamepad.Essentially this game has you (and/or your friends) as a wizard (with abilities to conjour boxes etc), a knight (with a sword and magical shield) and a thief (with a grappling hook and bow). All of these abilities are well bnalanced, and you will find yourself having to use all three characters as you work around the puzzles in your way. There might be any number of solutions to a given puzzle, so it's worth trying all the characters.Finally, this game has recieved a graphical overhaul and looks absolutely beautiful. The 'theme' is a very colourful fairytale look, with locations from enchanted forests with colourful flowers, giant leaves and massive snails to underground caverns with glowing crystals and bottomless pits. It's essentially a 2.5D game (3D animation in a 2D plane), but don't let that put you off - the backgrounds and lighting are very impressive.Definitely a 9/10 - loses the one point for the weak storyline and crazy boss level, but it's still a really fun game. Definitely worth picking up.

												What can I say, Trine is an impudently beautiful, masterfully executed and mighty clever platformer, full of great ideas and loaded with fun. I've now finished it two times, one time alone and one time in coop with a friend, and especially the coop experience, playing on the same computer, so much reminded me of the good old days where games used to be played like this. I so wish there be more such games for PC. Thumbs up and many thanks to Frozenbyte for upgrading our "old" Trines to the Enchanted Edition! That's what I call customer value. The sensationally improved graphics alone were worth playing through the game a second time, pushing them -almost- to Trine 2 class. Trine is full of nice little riddles and hidden loot. Even when playing alone, you constantly switch between the 3 main characters to make use of their unique skills. There are always multiple ways for solving problems and riddles, so you should never get stuck somewhere for too long. Only the precision of the controls could have been a bit better, but no worries, the game plays very well both with mouse/keyboard and controller. This game simply is a must-have for all fans of side scrolling platformers.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												Review for Trine Enchanted Edition and Trine 2: The Complete Story. read the full review @ http://blurbarians.blogspot.pt/2015/05/trine-trine-2.html    :D— Characters are fleshed out in a very light way. You get a quick background on their reasons to do whatever they are/want to do and that’s it. While this could be a negative point, you don’t really need to know more than what is told to you, and from then on the plot develops over the course of the game and through their dialogue, which is pretty nice. You get just the right amount of information to be able to enjoy the characters and their misadventures.— Characters are rather overpowered in the first game, thanks to the inventory system, allowing you to equip up to 9 artefacts to each character, improving stats or giving them health boosts (or outright giving them a second life). There is also the fact that each character has 3 ranks on their spells, and Amadeus in particular can summon more than twice the number of objects in the first game when compared to the second, including floating platforms which make it easy to bypass obstacles or reach difficult places. In the second game you have to use several skills from the three characters in combination to achieve the same results, making it more enjoyable.— Oh my god, the visuals. Every plant, leaf, statue, EVERYTHING looks absolutely wonderful. And don’t even get me started on some of the bosses or goblins in the second game. I don’t think I ever took as many screenshots per minute as I did in the Trine games. Back when these games came out in 2009 and 2011 respectively, playing on Extreme settings with a good framerate required a pretty solid rig. But seeing as my four year old GTX670 can keep it capped pretty much all of the time, it’s not a stretch anymore.— Occasional oddity in character physics, game has its quirks.— Amadeus is kind of useless in boss fights. He's a wizard that can summon boxes and move objects, meaning his offensive skills are non-existent.— Having to make movements with the cursor to summon different objects can be a headache and make the game unnecessarily hard on higher difficulties. It would have been easier to just press a specific button for each object (there are only 3 different objects anyways, 2 in the second game). Making said movements with a controller using the analog stick takes even longer than with a mouse and might get annoying after a while. In addition, the speed at which you can levitate certain objects (due to their weight) is painfully slow.— Everything is intuitive and makes sense, puzzles are relatively easy to solve by using simple logic or by just paying attention to your surroundings. Obviously, you'll have to solve them faster on harder difficulties if you don’t want to get killed. It certainly wouldn't have hurt to have harder puzzles, though that would probably have made certain achievements close to impossible, such as completing levels using only one single character.— Voice acting is wonderful, for some reason I can’t put my finger on. Characters seem genuinely friendly and trustful towards each other, except for the first couple of levels in the first game. Characters (especially Amadeus) have a lot of emotion behind them so it’s easy for the player to empathize with them, and all dialogue sounds natural and flows well. The narrator is nice too.— Music is very fitting and relaxing. Goes with the beautiful art and keeps you calm and focused.Conclusion: relaxing and fun gameplay, nice music, friendly characters and astounding visuals. If you want a nice co-op experience, go for it. If you want a good single-player experience, go for it too. Especially if you like platformers, puzzles, fantasy games and beautiful scenery.Final Gameplay Stats:Trine: 11 Hours played, 33 / 33 Achievements (100%)Trine 2: 55 Hours played, 97 / 97 Achievements (100%)

Posted: July 3, 2014
												Trine was a fun play through.  In general, the game plays quite fluidly, and rewards good gameplay with good action sequences.  This was only let down by the final level (more on that later).  The game is a cute magical re-imagining on some old multi-skill single-protagonist games, like Fury of the Furries.  It's set in a beautifully rendered world, with excellent voice acting and great music.  I have to hand it to the level designers.. very nice work.  The character animations are okay, with a lot of re-use of the same models and moves.  The puzzles are easy to solve, and make for a fast, rewarding play.  You never get stuck in one place for too long, and can always go back and re-play a level if you missed a special.  I particularly like that feature, as there are some levels which are actually quite a lot of fun to just explore around... Until the lava and spikey balls start.. then exploring becomes a pain.The final level was an exercise in annoyance and frustration.  Not too hard, I have to say, but the pace of the game totally changes, and a new game mechanic is introduced: rising lava.  Yeah, that old favourite from many an old game, like Killing Game Show.  I thought we were past that? oh well.. Then, once you finish, you get a bonus level with more rising lava.  Sheesh.  Thanks a heap.Apart from the last few minutes, I really really enjoyed playing this game.  It's not new, it's not outstanding, but it's eminently re-playable, and you can just put it down and pick it up without having to relearn everything from scratch, or go through lots of cutscenes.Thumbs-up!
